On Sat, 30 Oct 2004 18:16:16 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Guys, it's a very interesting paper.  

Thanks.

> I read it really fast just to
> get the main idea, so it's possible I missed this, but I didn't see
> any explanation of what S2, S3, C2, C3, and T2, and T3 were?  

Well, we say that S1 is the first normal square run, C1 is the first
normal circle run, etc.  So the others are just the other normal runs
for those shapes.  Maybe we should have spelled that out better.

> Also,
> it would be beneficial to have some discussion of cases (such as S3,
> I believe) where the match % was bad.  What did those shapes or
> orientations look like and why did it fail on them?

You're probably right.  There wasn't a discussion of the behavior of
individuals from unsuccessful runs.  The shape randomization works the
same for all runs, so it was simply the case that in about 1 out of 3
runs, the population did not evolve to perform well on the task.

> Anyway, I think it's really good work and a great start for this
> kind of research.  It's interesting that you don't need all the
> possible transformations to be able to succeed.  Of course, they may
> still offer advantages for more complex images.

Yeah.  Our next step is to be able to easily and consistently solve
the task in the paper.  If we can't get 100% on shapes, we're going to
have a hard time with more complex images.

> I wonder how good these would be at finding a particular shape in a
> crowded picture of shapes.  The ones you described that search by
> just going to one corner sound like they wouldn't be that good at a
> general "find the shape" task, but maybe if the task was explicitly
> to search they would evolve scanning strategies?

Yes, it would be interesting do apply this paradigm to object
detection in noisy images.  That obviously has a lot of real-world
applications, too.  Right now our focus is on
recognition/discrimination, but I'd definitely like to see how this
performs at related tasks.

Thanks for the feedback.

Derek
